facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1958 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment and order dated Februa

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 142 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 142 of 1957. Patnaik, for the appellant.

facts.text: Election held on March 8, 1957, for choosing members for the Mysore State Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: The election with which the case is concerned, was held on March 8, 1957, for choosing members for the Mysore State Legislative Assembly.

facts.text: Harihar was one of the constituencies for election to the Mysore State Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: One of the constituencies for the purposes of election to that Assembly was known as Harihar. The nomination papers filed by three persons, namely, Hanumanthappa,

facts.text: Nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao for election from Harihar constituency were rejected by the Returning Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The nomination papers filed by three persons, namely, Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao for election from that constituency were rejected by the Returning Officer on the ground that the first two of them were Patels and the third a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore

facts.text: Hanumanthappa and Siddappa were Patels of certain villages in Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the first two of them were Patels and the third a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore and as such they were all holders of offices of profit under the Mysore Government

facts.text: Guru Rao was a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: and the third a Shanbhog of certain villages in Mysore and as such they were all holders of offices of profit under the Mysore Government and consequently disqualified from membership of the Assembly under Art. 191.

facts.text: Appellant was declared elected from Harihar constituency as he obtained the larger number of votes.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this rejection two candidates were left to contest the election and the appellant, who was one of them, was declared elected as he obtained the larger number of votes at the poll.

facts.text: Six electors of Harihar constituency filed election petition under s. 100(1)(c) of Representation of the People Act, 1951, claiming appellant's election void due to improper rejection of nominations.

anchor.surface_text: Six electors of the Harihar constituency then filed the election petition for a declaration under s. 100(1)(c) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, that the election of the appellant was void on the ground that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao had been improperly rejected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the petition by order dated September 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the Election Tribunal by its order dated September 10, 1957. It held that the conditions of service of Patels and Shanbhogs were regulated by

facts.text: Election Tribunal held that Patels and Shanbhogs held offices of profit under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the conditions of service of Patels and Shanbhogs were regulated by the Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908, and that the mere fact that offices of Patels and Shanbhogs were hereditary was not by itself sufficient to establish that they were not offices under the Government.

facts.text: Six petitioners appealed to Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The six petitioners then appealed to the High Court of Mysore. The High Court by its judgment, dated February 26, 1958, allowed the appeal

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed the appeal on February 26, 1958, declared appellant's election void.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment, dated February 26, 1958, allowed the appeal and held that the offices of Patels and Shanbhogs were not offices under the Government. The election of the appellant was thereupon declared void.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal taken with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It is from this judgment that the present appeal to this Court has been taken with a certificate granted under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution. One of the six petitioners being dead,

facts.text: One of the six petitioners died, remaining five are respondents.

anchor.surface_text: One of the six petitioners being dead, the remaining five are the respondents in this appeal. There is no dispute that Hanumanthappa and Siddappa held the offices of Patels

facts.text: No dispute that Hanumanthappa and Siddappa held offices of Patels with lands allotted and cash allowances.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that Hanumanthappa and Siddappa held the offices of Patels and as remuneration for their services lands had been allotted to them and provision for cash allowances made.

facts.text: No dispute that Guru Rao was a Shanbhog with cash remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise it is no disputed that Guru Rao was a Shanbhog and had cash remuneration provided to him for his services. It is also clear and no challenged that Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties

facts.text: Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties to perform and are holders of offices.

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear and no challenged that Patels and Shanbhogs have specific duties to perform and are holders of offices. The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Mysore Government.

anchor.surface_text: All these clearly establish that Patels and shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government. In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored Election Tribunal order, dismissed election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

facts.text: Village offices governed by Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: Village Offices are no governed by the Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908. The election petition proceeds on this basis and both the Courts below have so held

holdings.text: Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: All these clearly establish that Patels and shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government. In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer and the election petition is without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment by Government perfects hereditary right; duties fixed and under Government control/supervision; remuneration from Government lands, revenue deductions treated as payments; removable by Government under s.7; no other entity to hold under.

holdings.text: Patels and Shanbhogs are holders of offices under the Mysore Government.

anchor.surface_text: The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government. The contention of the learned Advocate for the respondents is that Patels and Shanbhogs are not holders of offices under the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulated by Mysore Village Offices Act 1908; Government appoints even in hereditary cases; controls, remunerates, removes.

holdings.text: The nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer and the election petition is without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: As they held offices of profit under Government, disqualified under Art. 191.

holdings.text: Though there may be a hereditary right to hold an office, it is not held till an appointment to it is made by the Government and there is no one except the Government under whom the office can be held.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore come to the conclusion that though there may be a hereditary right to hold an office, it is not held till an appointment to it is made by the Government and that there is noone except the Government under whom the office can be held.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8 requires Government appointment to perfect succession right per personal law; even mandatory, appointment by Government; village communities lack corporate existence.

holdings.text: Hereditary right does not make the office one not under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Let us, however, ignore the restrictions on the hereditary right to the office mentioned in the Act and assume that the eldest heir in the eldest branch of the last holder of it, is entitled to succeed to the office when he vacates it. The question is, does

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes full hereditary right; still requires Government appointment; office held under appointer (Government).

holdings.text: The fact that a village officer cannot be dismissed at the pleasure of the Governor does not by itself establish that he does not hold office under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that the fact that an officer is not liable to dismissal at the pleasure of the Government does not by itself establish that he does not hold office under the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutes may limit pleasure doctrine (precedent: Gould v. Stuart); does not negate holding under Government.

holdings.text: Cash allowances deducted from revenue collected are payments by the Government out of its moneys.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules provide that where an officer deducts the cash allowance from the revenue collected by him and deposits the balance in the Government Treasury, his receipt for the amount deducted shall be considered equivalent to the payment into the Treasury of an equal sum in cash see rule 75 XIII of the Rules framed under the Act .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue belongs to Government; rules treat deduction as equivalent to full deposit and repayment.

anchor.surface_text: All these clearly establish that Patels and shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government. In this view of the matter it has to be held that the nomination papers of Hanumanthappa, Siddappa and Guru Rao were rightly rejected by the Returning Officer and the election petition is without substance.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.

The only point for determination in this appeal is whether they are holders of offices under the Mysore Government. The contention of the learned Advocate for the respondents is that Patels and Shanbhogs are not holders of offices under the Government.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court are set aside, and those of the Election Tribunal restored. The election petition is dismissed.
